questions.question_text: The finance department has started to use a new payment system that requires strict PII security restrictions on various network devices. The company decides to enforce the restrictions and configure all devices appropriately. Which of the following risk response strategies is being used?

discussion.content:
Maybe B. Mitigate?
The company is accepting a restriction, not a risk. By accepting the restriction, the company is mitigating future risks.
I sit next to a network guru and he is saying A. Black Hole based on the fact the engineer routed the traffic to a Null

The answer is B. Is true es black hole, but not remotely tigger uses any routing protocol to activaye the route protection. The statement does not say any about routing protocol. Using Cisco documentation https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/s/article/remotely-triggered-black-hole-filtering-dos-mitigation

comments.content: Thank you. This helped clear things up for me. I agree that it's B after reading the Black Hole Filtering Mitigation article. The examples given in the article are nearly identical to this one.

discussion.content:
A, black hole
to be clear, no router jockey would ever let this configuration on his network (looks like someone at CompTIA knows just enough Cisco IOS to confuse people). These steps will tag all traffic from the local network with route tag 101 and set a routing policy to destroy those packet by sending them to Null. External traffic from the webpage (BGP) will not be tagged and should make it to the web server as requested. There are... SOOO many things wrong with this set up and the idea that a network would be configured to allow this, but that's not the point I suppose. This is, in fact, an example of a black hole and the worst possible way to use Route Maps and Null interfaces together.

comments.content:
"On the other hand if the attacker is using source addresses in a predictable range, such as within the network 192.168.77.0, the following trigger
could be used to black hole traffic from these sources, as shown in Figure 5.
ip route 192.168.77.0 255.255.255.0 null0 tag 66 " SO YOU'RE RIGHT IT IS BLACK HOLE

discussion.content:
You can check the below Cisco document about the black hole.
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en_us/about/security/intelligence/blackhole.pdf

questions.question_text: A security administrator is updating a company's SCADA authentication system with a new application. To ensure interoperability between the legacy system and the new application, which of the following stakeholders should be involved in the configuration process before deployment? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A&E
Jason Dion: 
Many of the systems being run by the facilities manager are controlled by Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems

comments.content:
At first, I thought that too. But if the following is a good definition of compliance manager, why would we need one here?
"Compliance Manager designs and develops programs, policies, and practices to ensure that the organization complies with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. Manages the monitoring of business activities for compliance with applicable rules and regulations."

discussion.content: The network engineer needs to make sure the new SCADA device can talky-talky to the legacy system. Whenever you introduce system interoperability, the network engineering team needs to be involved so that the stacks can communicate.

Maybe: F. Compliance manager and not: A. Network engineer ?
I see no particular reason the network engineer should be involved. But it would make sense to make sure any new application is in compliance with any industry/company standards.

questions.question_text:
A security analyst is classifying data based on input from data owners and other stakeholders. The analyst has identified three data types:
1. Financially sensitive data
2. Project data
3. Sensitive project data
The analyst proposes that the data be protected in two major groups, with further access control separating the financially sensitive data from the sensitive project data. The normal project data will be stored in a separate, less secure location. Some stakeholders are concerned about the recommended approach and insist that commingling data from different sensitive projects would leave them vulnerable to industrial espionage.
Which of the following is the BEST course of action for the analyst to recommend?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Agreed, Data Owners are senior steak holders

comments.content: A stakeholder is anyone who has a vested interest in the outcome. which includes the dataowners.

Correct, but if data owners are telling you they're concerned with espionage due to commingling data - which is a polite way of saying can't do it that way - then, a sec analyst needs to listen to that. That is why, for me, B is the only viable answer here.

Data owners are stakeholders. But I do agree that the security analyst should be doing an quantitative assessment to either "accept or reject stakeholder's concerns." Basically, prove to them that they are either right or wrong. If you just approach the stakeholders and ask what they think are sufficient controls, then what's your job as a SECURITY analyst? You are the SME. Show them you did your due diligence and document.

discussion.content:
I think A
1) Stakeholders don't determine data classification, data owners do. You can accept or reject the concerns of the stakeholders, they probably read an internet article about an unrelated hacked systems for espionage and now insist on not using a specific design (this literally happened to me on a job once)
2) As a security analyst, your job is to analyze threats. Doing a quantitative assessment of how likely it is for a data system to be breached and/or stolen is like... the job. It's the whole thing. Meeting with stakeholders and coddling them is not.

comments.content: On second thought: separating "project data" from "sensitive project data" seems tricky. I would want to make sure to have a solution approved by the stakeholders.

discussion.content:
Maybe: D. Increase the number of available data storage devices to provide enough capacity for physical separation of non-sensitive project data?
Storage is cheap. A 1TB HDD costs $40. A 4TB HDD costs $80. Less expensive than the time it takes to organize a meeting.

choices.C: Use qualitative methods to determine aggregate risk scores for each project and use the derived scores to more finely segregate the data.
choices.A: Conduct a quantitative evaluation of the risks associated with commingling the data and reject or accept the concerns raised by the stakeholders.
choices.B: Meet with the affected stakeholders and determine which security controls would be sufficient to address the newly raised risks.
choices.D: Increase the number of available data storage devices to provide enough capacity for physical separation of non-sensitive project data.

choices.C: A shared workstation was physically accessible in a common area of the contractor's office space and was compromised by an attacker using a USB exploit, which resulted in gaining a local administrator account. Using the local administrator credentials, the attacker was able to move laterally to the server hosting the database with sensitive information.
choices.A: The attacker harvested the hashed credentials of an account within the database administrators group after dumping the memory of a compromised machine. With these credentials, the attacker was able to access the database containing sensitive information directly.
choices.D: After successfully using a watering hole attack to deliver an exploit to a machine, which belongs to an employee of the contractor, an attacker gained access to a corporate laptop. With this access, the attacker then established a remote session over a VPN connection with the server hosting the database of sensitive information.
choices.B: An account, which belongs to an administrator of virtualization infrastructure, was compromised with a successful phishing attack. The attacker used these credentials to access the virtual machine manager and made a copy of the target virtual machine image. The attacker later accessed the image offline to obtain sensitive information.

comments.content: I wish there was a mute button for all your comments

discussion.content: Why not: D. After successfully using a watering hole attack to deliver an exploit to a machine, which belongs to an employee of the contractor, an attacker gained access to a corporate laptop. With this access, the attacker then established a remote session over a VPN connection with the server hosting the database of sensitive information ?

questions.question_text:
A government contractor was the victim of a malicious attack that resulted in the theft of sensitive information. An analyst's subsequent investigation of sensitive systems led to the following discoveries:
✑ There was no indication of the data owner's or user's accounts being compromised.
✑ No database activity outside of previous baselines was discovered.
✑ All workstations and servers were fully patched for all known vulnerabilities at the time of the attack.
✑ It was likely not an insider threat, as all employees passed polygraph tests.
Given this scenario, which of the following is the MOST likely attack that occurred?
